SENT.plain: Autism is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by impairments in social skills, language, and behavior
It is now clear that autism is not a disease, but a syndrome characterized by phenotypic and genetic complexity
The etiology of autism is still poorly understood
Available evidence from a variety of sources strongly suggests that many genetic disorders are frequently associated with autism for their similar phenotypes

Based on this fact, this review begins by highlighting several principal genetic syndromes consistently associated with autism (fragile X, tuberous sclerosis, Angelman syndrome, Pader-Willi syndrome, Rett syndrome, Down syndrome and Turner syndrome)
These genetic disorders include both chromosome disorders and single gene disorders
By comparing the similar phenotype, protein marker and candidate genes, we might make some breakthrough in the mechanism of autism and other genetic disorders
